comments.body: Um, isn't this going to mask bugs?  Why wouldn't you fix the cause of the `SandboxViolation`???

It's an upstream bug that has been fixed in newer versions of setuptools/distribute. Writing to `/dev/null` should not trigger a `SandboxViolation`. While we could make an effort to only catch a `SandboxViolation` rather than `DistutilsError` (e.g. get the exception object and check if the name of its type is exactly `'SandboxViolation'`), but given the code inside the `try:` block, I think that `SandboxViolation` is the only subclass of `DistutilsError` that could be raised.
FWIW, this was only fixed in distribute at the time I wrote this. However, setuptools 0.7, which merges in distribute, has been released, and it contains the fix.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +224,228 @@        p = sp.Popen(["gcc", "-print-multiarch"], stdout=sp.PIPE,
                stderr=tmp)
    except (OSError, DistutilsError):
        # OSError if gcc is not installed, or SandboxViolation (DistutilsError
        # subclass) if an old setuptools bug is triggered (see gh-3160).

comments.body:
The above looks correct, but it took me a couple of minutes to understand the comment and the use of `del`. How about replacing the whole if clause with:

```
# From `check_libs` we get keys "libraries" and "library_dirs",
# while we need only key "runtime_library_dirs" with those paths
dict_append(info, runtime_library_dirs=i['library_dirs'])
```

It was more to be consistent in that if later revisions of check_libs
returns more than the two keys (libraries and library_dirs). In that
_future_ case would any additional keys also get passed. Hence the obscure
delete, pop sequence.
It may be overkill?

2015-02-25 9:53 GMT+01:00 Ralf Gommers notifications@github.com:

> In numpy/distutils/system_info.py
> https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/5597#discussion_r25325312:
> 
> > @@ -498,17 +505,46 @@ def calc_libraries_info(self):
> >                  dict_append(info, **i)
> >              else:
> >                  log.info('Library %s was not found. Ignoring' % (lib))
> > -            i = self.check_libs(r_dirs, [lib])
> > -            if i is not None:
> > -                # Swap library keywords found to runtime_library_dirs
> > -                # the libraries are insisting on the user having defined
> > -                # them using the library_dirs, and not necessarily by
> > -                # runtime_library_dirs
> > -                del i['libraries']
> > -                i['runtime_library_dirs'] = i.pop('library_dirs')
> > -                dict_append(info, **i)
> 
> The above looks correct, but it took me a couple of minutes to understand
> the comment and the use of del. How about replacing the whole if clause
> with:
> 
> # From `check_libs` we get keys "libraries" and "library_dirs",
> 
> # while we need only key "runtime_library_dirs" with those paths
> 
> dict_append(info, runtime_library_dirs=i['library_dirs'])
> 
> â€”
> Reply to this email directly or view it on GitHub
> https://github.com/numpy/numpy/pull/5597/files#r25325312.

## 

Kind regards Nick

Then all those extra keys would already be updated by this code above right?

```
        i = self.check_libs(dirs, [lib])
        if i is not None:
            dict_append(info, **i)
```

Yes, but that would also add the libraries key, which should be provided by the library key and library_dirs, not intrinsically by runtime_library_dirs. I did this so that library_dirs has precedence for actual libraries, and runtime_library_dirs only works for those directories listed.
So it is a "hack" to not re-create a check_libs routine only for the runtime libs.
The way I did it it will only allow runtime_library_dirs to be added iff the libraries also exists in those paths (this is what check_libs does).

If your above code would be used, all libraries would be added twice to the list. Also we need to transfer library_dirs to runtime_library_dirs, hence the pop to the other key.

###### site1.cfg

```
[lapack]
libraries = lapack
library_dirs = /opt/lapack
```

Linking command: `... -L/opt/lapack -llapack`.  
Here `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` is needed if shared lapack is shared.

###### site2.cfg

```
[lapack]
libraries = lapack
library_dirs = /opt/lapack
runtime_library_dirs = /opt/lapack
```

Linking command: `... -L/opt/lapack -Wl,-rpath=/opt/lapack -llapack`.  
Here the runtime library directory will be set, `LD_LIBRARY_PATH` not needed any more.

###### site3.cfg

```
[lapack]
libraries = lapack
runtime_library_dirs = /opt/lapack
```

Linking command: `... -Wl,-rpath=/opt/lapack -llapack`.

diffHunk:
@@ -1,1 +519,523 @@                del i['libraries']
                i['runtime_library_dirs'] = i.pop('library_dirs')
                dict_append(info, **i)
            else:
                log.info('Runtime library %s was not found. Ignoring' % (lib))
